The Buddha said:
What is the foolish dharma?
A foolish person has three characteristics of foolishness, marks of foolishness, and appearances of foolishness, namely, a foolish person accomplishes and speaks of foolishness.
What are the three?
A foolish person thinks evil thoughts, speaks evil words, and does evil deeds, and for this reason a foolish person is called foolish.
If a foolish person does not think evil thoughts, speak evil words, or do evil deeds, one should not call that foolish person foolish.
Because a foolish person thinks evil thoughts, speaks evil words, and does evil deeds, therefore a foolish person is called foolish.
That foolish person in this very life will experience three kinds of mental and physical suffering.
How does a foolish person experience three kinds of mental and physical suffering?
A foolish person, whether walking, sitting in a gathering, in the streets, in the market, or at a crossroads, speaks about things that correspond to a foolish person.
A foolish person kills, takes what is not given, engages in sexual misconduct, speaks falsely, up to having wrong views, and accomplishes other immeasurable evil and unwholesome dharmas.
If one accomplishes immeasurable evil and unwholesome dharmas, others, having seen this, will speak of one's evil.
Having heard this, the foolish person thinks:

'If one who has accomplished immeasurable evil and unwholesome dharmas is seen by others and they speak of his evil, I also have these immeasurable evil and unwholesome dharmas. If others know, they will also speak of my evil.'
This is called the foolish person who in the present life physically and mentally experiences the utmost sorrow and suffering.
Furthermore, the foolish person also sees the king's men arresting criminals and punishing them in various ways,
such as cutting off their hands, cutting off their feet, cutting off both hands and feet, cutting off their ears, cutting off their noses,
and cutting off both ears and nose, or cutting them to pieces, pulling out their beards, pulling out their hair, or pulling out both beards and hair,
or putting them in a cage and burning them with fire wrapped in cloth, or pressing them with sand wrapped in grass and burning them with fire, or
putting them in an iron donkey's belly, or putting them in an iron pig's mouth, or placing them in an iron tiger's mouth and burning them,
Or placed in a copper cauldron, or put in an iron cauldron to be boiled, or cut into pieces, or

beaten with sticks, or struck with staves, or impaled alive, or beheaded.
When that foolish person sees this, he thinks:

'If one who has accomplished immeasurable evil and unwholesome dharmas is known by the king and caught, he will be punished like this. I also have these immeasurable evil and unwholesome dharmas. If the king knows, he will also punish me severely.'
Thus, this is called the second suffering and distress of body and mind that a foolish person experiences in the present life.

Furthermore, that foolish person who engages in bodily misconduct, verbal misconduct, and mental misconduct, if at some time they become sick and suffer, whether lying on a bed, couch, or on the ground, their body experiences extreme pain and suffering, to the point of death.

Whatever bodily misconduct, verbal misconduct, and mental misconduct they have, at that time they hang above them, just like in the evening when the sun sets on a high mountain, its shadow hangs down on the ground. In the same way, whatever bodily misconduct, verbal misconduct, and mental misconduct they have, at that time they hang above them.
They think like this:
'This is my bodily misconduct, verbal misconduct, and mental misconduct, hanging above me.

I did not do good deeds in the past, but did many bad things. If there is a place for those who do bad things, who are violent and do unreasonable things, who do not do good deeds, who do not do wholesome things, who do not do fearful things, to which I have gone for refuge and rely on, I have gone to that bad place.
From this, remorse arises. Having given rise to remorse, the unwholesome person dies and ends their life unskillfully.
This is called the third sorrow and suffering experienced by the foolish person's body and mind in the present life.

Furthermore, that foolish person practices bodily misconduct, verbal misconduct, and mental misconduct. Having practiced bodily misconduct, verbal misconduct, and mental misconduct, because of this and relying on this, when their body breaks up and their life ends, they will certainly go to a bad realm of existence, being born in hell.
Having been born there, they will experience painful results that are entirely unlikable, unenjoyable, and undesirable. If one were to say:
'That which is entirely unlikable, unenjoyable, and undesirable is said to be hell.
Why is that?
Because that hell is entirely unlikable, unenjoyable, and undesirable.
At that time, a certain monk rose from his seat, bared his right shoulder, placed his palms together facing the Buddha, and said:

Monks!
What is the suffering in hell?

Sentient beings are born in hell. After being born there, the wardens seize them and use an iron ax, burning and blazing, to cut up their bodies, making them into octagonal, hexagonal, square, or round shapes, either tall or short, good or bad.

They are thus tortured and afflicted with pain for many years, up to hundreds of thousands of years, experiencing immeasurable suffering, extremely heavy and severe, but never dying. They must endure until their evil and unwholesome karma is exhausted. This is called the suffering of hell.

What is the suffering of hell?

Sentient beings are born in hell. After being born there, the wardens seize them and use an iron chisel, burning and blazing, to cut up their bodies, making them into octagonal, hexagonal, square, or round shapes, either tall or short, good or bad.

They are thus examined and tortured, suffering extreme pain for many years, up to hundreds of thousands of years, experiencing immeasurable suffering, extremely severe pain, but never dying, until their evil and unwholesome karma is exhausted. This is called the suffering of hell.

What is the suffering of hell?

When sentient beings are born in hell, after being born there, the wardens seize them and force them to sit on an iron spear that is burning and blazing, then they use iron pincers to pry open their mouths, and put an iron ball that is burning and blazing into their mouths, burning their lips, burning their tongues, burning their gums, burning their throats, burning their hearts, burning their stomachs, and coming out from below their bodies.

They are thus examined and tortured, suffering extreme pain for many years, up to hundreds of thousands of years, experiencing immeasurable suffering, extremely severe pain, but never dying, until their evil and unwholesome karma is exhausted. This is called the suffering of hell.

What is the suffering of hell?

When sentient beings are born in hell, after being born there, the jailers seize them and make them sit forcefully on an iron stake that is burning and blazing, then they use iron pincers to pry open their mouths and pour molten copper into their mouths, burning their lips, burning their tongues, burning their gums, burning their throats, burning their hearts, burning their stomachs, and coming out from their bodies below.

Monks!

In that hell there is a place called the Six Rebirths. what is the suffering of the animals?

If sentient beings are born among animals, they smell the smell of human feces and urine, and immediately run towards it to eat it.
What is that like?
It refers to chickens, pigs, dogs, wolves, crows, owls, and vultures.
Foolish people, due to originally being attached to the taste of food, engage in evil bodily actions, evil verbal actions, and evil mental actions.

Having engaged in evil bodily actions, evil verbal actions, and evil mental actions, because of this and relying on this, when the body perishes and life ends, they are born among animals, eating feces and impurities. This is called the suffering of animals.
Monks!

Having been born there, they are either blind, lame, with short arms, hunchbacked, or left-handed, with ugly faces like sheep, ugly, short-lived, and enslaved by others. They engage in evil bodily actions, evil verbal and mental actions.

Having engaged in evil bodily actions, evil verbal and mental actions, because of this and on account of this, when their body breaks up and their life ends, they go to a bad place, are reborn in hell.

' He loses his slaves and wife, and then hangs himself upside down in a smoky house.

This practice is very rare, losing slaves, losing wives and children, and then taking one's own body, hanging upside down in a smoky house.
Bhikkhus!
This practice is what should be practiced, practicing evil bodily actions, practicing evil verbal and mental actions.

Bhikkhus!
This practice is the most unlovable, truly unpleasant, and not what is thought of.
Bhikkhus!
Is it not a complete explanation of the foolish Dharma?

Yes.
World-Honored One!
It is a complete explanation of the foolish Dharma.
The World-Honored One said:
What is the wise Dharma?
For the wise person, there are three characteristics of wisdom, the appearance of wisdom, which is said to be accomplished by the wise person.
What are the three?
A wise person thinks good thoughts, speaks good words, and does good deeds, and therefore a wise person speaks of wisdom.
If a wise person does not think good thoughts, speak good words, or do good deeds, then a wise person should not speak of wisdom.
Because a wise person thinks good thoughts, speaks good words, and does good deeds, that wise person speaks of wisdom.
A wise person, in this very life, experiences three kinds of joy and happiness with body and mind.
How does a wise person experience three kinds of joy and happiness with body and mind in this very life?
A wise person, whether walking, sitting in an assembly, on the street, in the market, or at a crossroads, speaks of things that accord with a wise person.

The wise person abandons killing, abstains from killing, does not take what is not given, engages in sexual misconduct, speaks falsely, and so on, up to abandoning wrong views and attaining right views, and accomplishes other immeasurable good dharmas.
If one accomplishes immeasurable good dharmas, others, having seen this, will praise them.
When the wise person hears this, they will think like this:
'If one accomplishes immeasurable good dharmas, others, having seen this, will praise them. I also have these immeasurable good dharmas. If others know this, they will also praise me.'
This is called the wise person, in the present life, their body and mind then receiving the foremost joy and bliss.

Furthermore, that wise person, having practiced good conduct with the body, speech, and mind, if they become ill, whether lying on a bed, a couch, or the ground, and experience extreme pain and severe suffering, to the point of death,

their good conduct with the body, speech, and mind, at that time, hangs above them, just like the shadow of a mountain in the evening when the sun sets, hanging down on the ground. In the same way, their good conduct with the body, speech, and mind, at that time, hangs above them.
They think like this:
'This is my good conduct with the body, speech, and mind, hanging above me. In the past, I did not do evil, but created much merit.

If there is a place where one does not do evil, is not violent, does not do unreasonable things, does good, does what is wholesome, and is fearful, where one takes refuge and relies on, I will go to that good place.
And do not give rise to regret, and having not given rise to regret, die well and have a good end.
This is called the third happiness and joy that a wise person experiences in the present world, both in body and mind.

Furthermore, that wise person practices good bodily actions, good verbal and mental actions. 'What is entirely delightful, entirely enjoyable, and agreeable to the mind, is said to be a good place.
